p: Alcohol use and IPV perpetration are highly prevalent in Vietnam and largely shaped by sociocultural norms that stem from Confucianism [ 18]. Men are the key decision-makers and income earners of their households [ 19, 20]. Men's use of violence or aggression to exercise control is often seen as necessary to maintain a superior position [ 19, 20]. Studies estimate that 58% of married women reported ever experiencing IPV by their husbands [ 21] and 37% of men reported ever perpetrating IPV against their wife [ 22]. Men's alcohol use is also closely tied to their masculinity [ 23] and it is strongly encouraged through cultural practices and informal and formal social events [ 23– 26]. The World Health Organization found that the annual per capita consumption of pure alcohol in Vietnam was 5.1 liters [ 14], which is greater than the global consumption of pure alcohol per capita (4.3 to 4.7 liters) [ 27]. Traditional gender norms characterize men as having volatile tempers and alcohol is perceived as a driver of men's aggressive or violent behavior [ 20]. Men’s use of violence under the influence of alcohol is often viewed as uncontrollable and an innate demonstration of masculinity [ 19, 20, 23].
